qas.question: What three services make up the armed forces of the UK?

answers.text: the British Army, the Royal Navy, and the Royal Air Force

qas.question: What did David Lloyd George's coalition government reject in 1921?

answers.text: The formation of a united ministry of defence

qas.question: When was the Chiefs of Staff Committee formed?
Who created the position of Minister for Coordination of Defence?
What post did Lord Chatfield hold until 1940?
When was the creation of a Royal Navy rejected by David Lloyd George's coalition government?

plausible_answers.text: for the purposes of inter-Service co-ordination

qas.question: Why was the a group of British civil servantsformed in 1923?

plausible_answers.text: the position of Minister for Coordination of Defence

qas.question: What was created by Neville Chamberlain in the 1920"s?
When was the Royal Air Force disbanded?

plausible_answers.text: the British Army, the Royal Navy, and the Royal Air Force

qas.question: What three services were limited by political influence in 1923?

context: During the 1920s and 1930s, British civil servants and politicians, looking back at the performance of the state during World War I, concluded that there was a need for greater co-ordination between the three Services that made up the armed forces of the United Kingdom—<a0_0><b9_0>the British Army, the Royal Navy, and the Royal Air Force<b9_0/><a0_0/>. <a1_0>The formation of a united ministry of defence<a1_0/> was rejected by David Lloyd George's coalition government <b5_0>in 1921<b5_0/>; but the Chiefs of Staff Committee was formed in <a2_0>1923<a2_0/>, <b6_0>for the purposes of inter-Service co-ordination<b6_0/>. As rearmament became a concern during the 1930s, <a3_0>Stanley Baldwin<a3_0/> created <b7_0>the position of <a4_0>Minister for Coordination of Defence<b7_0/><a4_0/>. Lord Chatfield held the post until the fall of Neville Chamberlain's government <b8_0>in 1940<b8_0/>; his success was limited by his lack of control over the existing Service departments and his limited political influence.
